contentSummary: Axway's case study on how API integration has helped Permata Bank enter new markets, extend its customer base, and increase the size of transactions conducted through the bank.

existingPortfolioEnhancement.type: Customer reach, adoption, focusing on existing/traditional bank customer segments
existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: New accounts increased by 375% during 2016-2019. Transaction volume grew at a 274% CAGR in 2016-2019.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: Working with new fintech partners in wealth management and P2P lenders, as well as enabling payments APIs for platform businesses like e-commerce, rideshare, payment gateways, and online gaming providers, PermataBank has entered new markets, extended its customer base, and increased the size of transactions conducted through the bank.

networkOptimisation.content: Working with new fintech partners in wealth management and P2P lenders, as well as enabling payments APIs for platform businesses like e-commerce, rideshare, payment gateways, and online gaming providers, PermataBank has entered new markets, extended its customer base, and increased the size of transactions conducted through the bank.

Working with new fintech partners in wealth management and P2P lenders, as well as enabling payments APIs for platform businesses like e-commerce, rideshare, payment gateways, and online gaming providers, PermataBank has entered new markets, extended its customer base, and increased the size of transactions conducted through the bank.

source.label: Other related contents/information on Starling Bank's marketplace:

contentSummary: Fintech Fraternity's deep dive on Starling Bank, including the bank's product capacbilities and strategy, its customer acquisition strategy & results, and its financial performance.
investmentCost: Starling Bank has spent over GBP20 million on developing its banking technologies, which run on public cloud infrastructure.

existingPortfolioEnhancement.type: Customer reach, adoption, focusing on existing/traditional bank customer segments
existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: - Retail banking custormers: 100,000 new within 10 months since the launch in May 2017. The number reached 1.3 million by August 2020. - Business banking customers: 12,000 new within 10 months since the launch in May 2017. The number reached 200,000 by August 2020. - A typical customer has mutliple types of accounts across retail and business offering.
33% of active business customers have an active Marketplace integration in August 2020.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: APIs are being leveraged to enable three of Starling's five key revenue income streams: interchange (payment processing fees), marketplace commissions, and platform services revenues.

networkOptimisation.content: - There are currently 42 partnerships at the core of Starling, ranging from lending, insurance, wealth, B2B banking services and business tools, and others. - Starling Bank has picked up steam with Marketplace integrations in 2019, adding 8 providers across retail and business offerings. It has added another 9 new providers in 2020. Focus remains on SME services.

enhanceFinancialPerformance.content: The number of payments processed by Starling Banking-as-a-Service APIs are doubling month on month. Income from platform services grew from GBP5,000 in November 2017 to GBP213,000 in November 2018, then to GBP1,556,000 in November 2019.
Administrative expenses per account depict a stable trend: From GBP388 in November 2017, down to GBP84 in November 2018 and GBP85 in November 2019.

contentSummary: Axway's case study on how API integration has helped Permata Bank enter new markets, extend its customer base, and increase the size of transactions conducted through the bank.

existingPortfolioEnhancement.type: Customer reach, adoption, focusing on existing/traditional bank customer segments
existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: Customer base of Marcus: 0.2 million in 2016 grew to 5.0 million in 2019. Deposit balances at Marcus: USD12.0 billion grew to USD60 billion. Loans/cards balances at Marcus: USD0.2billion to USD7.0 billion

networkOptimisation.content: has sealed deals with Amazon to provide lines of credit to merchants and with Apple to provide credit cards

enhanceFinancialPerformance.content: Revenue of Marcus: USD2.0 million in 2016 grew to USD860 million in 2019.

contentSummary: BBVA's press release on Holvi's acquisition
investmentCost: Acquisitions and investments play an important role in providing the digital experience and fulfilling BBVA's plans. In 2015, the Group acquired a strategic 29.5% stake in Atom , the UK's first exclusively mobile bank, and completed the purchase of Spring Studio , a US design firm, leader in user experience. In 2014, BBVA acquired Madiva Soluciones , a big data and cloud computing services startup, and Simple , a technology firm that has changed the way people manage their money

existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: Teppo Paavola, head of New Digital Businesses at BBVA, said: “We are very happy with Holvi as we share the vision that technology should benefit the client. Through digital, Holvi brings a new approach to banking for small businesses, where services are essential for the future of a business, as is the fact that billing management is integrated into its offer.

contentSummary: News article on Standard Bank's acquisition of TradeSafe
investmentCost: Standard Bank acquires 35% of TradeSfae which has an API gateway. As part of the investment, Standard Bank has appointed two non-executive directors to the TradeSafe board. Standard Bank also has management oversight of TradeSafe’s escrow account and is fully involved in the process for payment instructions that TradeSafe initiates.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: CEO of TradeSafe, Jethro O’Brien, says: “Both TradeSafe and Standard Bank realised the necessity for a fast, secure, and affordable escrow solution in the wake of the increasing volume of scams, fraud and unpaid invoice payments in South African commerce. Our fees come in at a fifth of what a reputable law firm or bank would charge in a transaction.

source.label: Danske Bank and DNB invest in Nordic API Gateway (18 December 2018)
DNB and Danske Bank top up investment in Nordic API Gateway (23 April 2020)

contentSummary: News article on Standard Bank's acquisition of TradeSafe
investmentCost: 18 December 2018: DNB and Danske Bank have invested EUR5.2 million in Nordic API Gateway. Dasnke Bank has topped up its initial investment of EUR3.3 million in Spiir made in May with a further EUR1.3 million, and made room for DNB, as the three parties bid to position Nordic API Gateway as an industry infrastructure for PSD2. 23 April 2020: DNB and Danske Bank have invested a further EUR4.6 million in Spiir, the Danish financial app as it prepares for a full-scale launch of its Nordic API Gateway subsidiary in Europe.

existingPortfolioEnhancement.type: Customer reach, adoption, focusing on existing/traditional bank customer segments
existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: Tapping Nordic API Gateway's account information service, the app will let users - whether they are DNB customers or not - access all personal and business accounts from across Norway.

Per Kristian Næss Fladset, head, Open Banking, DNB, says: With Nordic API Gateway, we’re taking full advantage of the opportunities PSD2 creates. It’s a unique opportunity to aggregate account information from other players to give our customers a full financial overview of our new mobile bank.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: DNB in February extended the account aggregation tool to incorporate account-to-account payments from any bank listed in the mobile banking app.

source.label: Danske Bank invests in personal finance app Spiir (16 May 2018)
DNB and Danske Bank top up investment in Nordic API Gateway (23 April 2020)
DNB and Danske Bank top up investment in Nordic API Gateway (23 April 2020)

contentSummary: News reported that Nordic API Gateway has extended its partnership with Denmark's leading bank to enable customers to pay from other banks within Danske Bank’s mobile banking app.
investmentCost: 18 December 2018: Dasnke Bank has topped up its initial investment of EUR3.3 million in Spiir made in May with a further EUR1.3 million. 23 April 2020: DNB and Danske Bank have invested a further EUR4.6 million in Spiir, the Danish financial app as it prepares for a full-scale launch of its Nordic API Gateway subsidiary in Europe.

existingPortfolioEnhancement.type: Customer reach, adoption, focusing on existing/traditional bank customer segments
existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: With more than 3 million personal banking customers across the Nordics, Danske Bank has  experienced a rising customer trend as more have started banking with several banks over the past  couple of years. As an addition to giving customers a full financial overview with account aggregation  back in 2018 as the first Nordic bank to do so across Denmark, Sweden, Finland and Norway, Danske  Bank is now taking their open banking strategy to the next level by implementing open banking  payments, making it possible for their customers to transfer money frictionlessly between​ ​all their  accounts in one place regardless of what bank they hold.

networkOptimisation.content: We’ve been  working closely with Nordic API Gateway since 2017 and we’re happy to continue developing the  partnership, giving our customers a huge flexibility as they’re now able to make payments and  transfers between their own accounts across several different banks. For us, it’s all about making it  easier for customers to gain a full financial overview - no matter how many banks they have. - ​Line Munkholm​, Group Head of Digital Banking at  Danske Bank

contentSummary: Discusses how Bendigo & Adelaide Bank use their open banking neobank Up as a testbed for digital technologies. The new infrastructure uses API gateways and cloud infratsructure

efficiencyEnhancement.content: “Open banking is at the forefront of enabling us to simplify and modernise the way we do business across the bank,“ said Bendigo and Adelaide Bank’s chief transformation officer Ryan Brosnahan. Open banking saw Bendigo and Adelaide Bank stand up a cloud infrastructure as well as supporting “governance and assurance frameworks to enable us to run material workloads in the cloud,” Brosnahan said. “The move to cloud has also driven a renewed and accelerated focus around DevOps. We've also taken the opportunity to build new data capabilities for much broader enterprise benefit, including real time data streaming, API gateways, and a new cloud data platform. We've also implemented a federated identity management solution that will progressively extend to manage the identity and consent process for all of our customer and staff applications. And with the added complexity of multiple core banking systems across our brands, our broader transformation agenda is actively simplifying and modernising the underlying core banking platforms.”

contentSummary: NAB has creadetd 1300 APIs for internal and external use

existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: “Many of [our 1200] APIs link to our customers to enable great integrations into their environments and really help then digitise their environments in a way that integrates with their banking services,” Executive for enterprise technology Steve Day said.”

networkOptimisation.content: “We've built interfaces to things like Xero, so Xero can now interface to us directly. We built interfaces to realestate.com.au so that people, as they buy houses, can actually get real time information back out on our products and services through these APIs and what they'd be able to loan, etc,” Day said.“We're creating a lot more of these interfaces so not only can we provide digital windows into our business but also we can open it up to allow other third parties to provide services.”

“We've built interfaces to things like Xero, so Xero can now interface to us directly. We built interfaces to realestate.com.au so that people, as they buy houses, can actually get real time information back out on our products and services through these APIs and what they'd be able to loan, etc,” Day said.“We're creating a lot more of these interfaces so not only can we provide digital windows into our business but also we can open it up to allow other third parties to provide services.”

“We built interfaces to realestate.com.au so that people, as they buy houses, can actually get real time information back out on our products and services through these APIs and what they'd be able to loan, etc,” Day said.

source.label: DBS launches Southeast Asia's largest bank-led property marketplace ( 24 July 2018, with performance review of Car Marketplace and Electricity Marketplace)
DBS opens air travel marketplace (17 July 2019, with performance review of Property Marketplace)

contentSummary: A talk about differences between Digital/API Ecosystems, Marketplaces and Platforms by Alan Glickenhouse, API Strategist/IBM  at APIDays Helsinki 1-2 September 2020. Alan discussed DBS Bank's Property Martketplace as an interesting case study of a combination between a digital ecosystem and a API marketplace. DBS Property Marketplace is the one-stop shop for property buyers, made possible by integrating APIs. DBS has also implemented DBS Car Marketplace, DBS Electricity Marketplace and the most recent one DBS Air Travel Marketplace.

existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: Finextra news 17 July 2019: - Since its launch as Singapore’s largest direct seller-to-buyer car marketplace, DBS Car Marketplace has attracted more than 550,000 unique visits. - Customers can choose from more than 30 price plans offered by seven alternative electricity retailers on DBS Electricity Marketplace, which has registered more than 300,000 unique visits to date.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: - DBS Bank Press Release 24 July 2018: The site (DBS Car Marketplace) has also facilitated transactions consisting of car purchase, loans, insurance and credit card applications as well as purchase of car-related accessories. - Finextra news 17 July 2019: DBS Property Marketplace has in turn generated more than SGD 300 million in home loan requests within the first 12 months.

- Finextra news 17 July 2019: DBS Travel Marketplace marks DBS’ fourth such integrated digital marketplace, and its first payments-enabled one. The bank believes that by creating meaningful ecosystem partnerships (collaborating and innovating together with partners) through its marketplace platform, customers will benefit from a seamless, fuss-free experience bringing together the best of travel and banking solutions. For example, a customer who logs in with his DBS/POSB online banking credentials and consents to sharing his data will have his personal and payment details automatically pre-filled in his travel booking.

networkOptimisation.content: - Since its launch in August 2017 as Singapore’s largest direct seller-to-buyer car marketplace, in partnership with sgCarMart and Carro, DBS Car Marketplace has attracted some 350,000 unique visits. The bank has expanded its marketplace to include six established car dealers: Alpine Group; Select by Performance Premium Selection; Inchcape Pre-Owned; CarTimes; Orchard Credit; and Dickson. The marketplace also includes services from VICOM Ltd, the largest vehicle inspection and technical testing company in Singapore. - Since its launch in March this year, DBS Electricity Marketplace, which allows consumers to seamlessly switch to new electricity retailers iSwitch and Keppel Electric, has attracted some 190,000 unique visitors – almost double of the 108,000 eligible Jurong households. This indicates deep interest from consumers in the potential switching of electricity providers and bodes well for the electricity liberalisation which will happen by the end of the year. DBS looks forward to introducing more electricity retailers to the marketplace then.

source.label: Bank BRI: Accelerating Financial Inclusion with Apigee (9 July 2018)

contentSummary: Google Cloud's Bala Kasiviswanathan disccused how APIs and ecosystem strategies accelerate digital transformation, with an interesting example of Indonesia's Bank BRI's premium credit scoring API helping revenue and financial inclusion.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: “Indonesia’s Bank BRI, for example, made capabilities such as credit scoring available via an API as a paid service, which helped it to develop a digital network of “branchless” agents across many of the country’s most remote regions. This approach has not only extended Bank BRI’s services to new users in areas with little brick-and-mortar banking, but also contributed $50 million in revenue.“ - Bala Kasiviswanathan Director of Product Management, Google Cloud

efficiencyEnhancement.content: “Whereas Bank BRI recently needed as much as six months to onboard new partners, its API-first approach has reduced that to as little as one hour.“ - Bala Kasiviswanathan, Director of Product Management, Google Cloud

networkOptimisation.content: “Our network of over 320,000 branchless agents around Indonesia—particularly in the more rural eastern part of the country—is now enabled through our API-based apps to do cash-in and cash-out transactions. They can pay billers as well as offer a variety of services specific to different regions of Indonesia. This greatly helps to accelerate the number people who go from not having banking services to using a bank. We’re seeing a lot of startups beginning to work with expanding financial inclusion in rural regions. However, they don’t have the licenses to do payment engines, and we’re able to help them by extending our API payment engine to these services.“ - Kaspar Situmorang, Bank BRI (9 July 2018)

enhanceFinancialPerformance.content: “This approach has not only extended Bank BRI’s services to new users in areas with little brick-and-mortar banking, but also contributed $50 million in revenue.“ - Bala Kasiviswanathan Director of Product Management, Google Cloud (9 September 2020).

source.label: We’ve partnered with Infor to improve supply chain liquidity and reduce supply risk (6 Feb 2020)

contentSummary: Standard Chartered has signed an agreement with cloud supply chain firm Infor which will see the bank offer the tech firm’s Nexus network to clients.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: Michael Sugirin, global head of open account trade product management at Standard Chartered, says that 80% of the data used in matching is sourced from documents residing with external parties. “This manual matching process is time-consuming, often resulting in a delay of the trade financing cycle which impacts the supplier’s ability to meet their working capital needs, most of whom tend to be small and medium-sized businesses. This strategic partnership addresses this gap and reduces capital related costs and risk from the supply chain.”

networkOptimisation.content: Through the strategic agreement, Standard Chartered will refer clients to Infor and its Infor Nexus network. The agreement also enables Standard Chartered to “expand client relationships through digital transformation solutions.” - Rod Johnson, general manager and head of Americas at Infor.

source.label: Deutsche Bank to invest in financing platform Traxpay (24 July 2020)

What is Traxpay? Traxpay was designed to fit into your existing workflows. There is no software to download, and it works via API with any web browser, online portal, or directly through your ERP system.

contentSummary: Deutsche Bank has bought a minority stake in Traxpay, a financing platform for suppliers.
investmentCost: Deutsche Bank has bought a minority stake in Traxpay, a financing platform for suppliers.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: Buyers and sellers who use the dynamic discounting solution that Traxpay offers benefit from flexible payment terms for goods and services, which means buyers get a discount depending on when they decide to pay. Retailers and suppliers can use the Traxpay platform to decide whether they want to settle a payable earlier and receive a discount in their individual case or whether they would like a bank to offer them interim financing.

efficiencyEnhancement.content: “The use of a single platform brings great transparency and efficiency gains for customers and suppliers as well as for the financing partners,” Traxpay CEO Markus Rupprecht.

networkOptimisation.content: By investing in Traxpay, Deutsche Bank is using the fintech’s platform technology to expand its supply chain finance offering. Other banks are being encouraged to join as investors and cooperating partners to further expand the platform. Traxpay will maintain its existing cooperations with other banks.

source.label: Link to Tink's 2020 Open Banking survey report:

contentSummary: A blog article from Jan van Vonno, Research Director at Tink, summarising the key points from their 2020 open banking survey report.
investmentCost: “Our data also revealed that financial institutions are ramping up their investments in open banking — with median open banking investment budgets for European financial institutions typically lying between €50-€100m, with spend exceeding €100m for 45% of financial institutions surveyed.“ - Jan van Vonno, Research Director at Tink

networkOptimisation.content: “Finally, financial institutions should look to build partnerships with fintechs to accelerate innovation and provide them with the technology, expertise and vision to drive open banking value creation — helping them realise their objectives. In many cases, this is already happening — with our research revealing that 69% have increased their number of fintech partnerships in 2019, while the majority of executives are also working with more than one partner. These partnerships need to be set up in a smart way, however, with fintechs able to navigate the complex procurement processes and onboarding requirements that many financial institutions have in place.“ - Jan van Vonno, Research Director at Tink

source.label: Deutsche Bank to invest in financing platform Traxpay (24 July 2020)

What is Traxpay? Traxpay was designed to fit into your existing workflows. There is no software to download, and it works via API with any web browser, online portal, or directly through your ERP system.

contentSummary: Deutsche Bank has bought a minority stake in Traxpay, a financing platform for suppliers.
investmentCost: Deutsche Bank has bought a minority stake in Traxpay, a financing platform for suppliers.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: Buyers and sellers who use the dynamic discounting solution that Traxpay offers benefit from flexible payment terms for goods and services, which means buyers get a discount depending on when they decide to pay. Retailers and suppliers can use the Traxpay platform to decide whether they want to settle a payable earlier and receive a discount in their individual case or whether they would like a bank to offer them interim financing.

efficiencyEnhancement.content: “The use of a single platform brings great transparency and efficiency gains for customers and suppliers as well as for the financing partners,” Traxpay CEO Markus Rupprecht.

contentSummary: ClearBank is to offer clients the ability to create multi-currency bank accounts via a an API-based connection to JPMorgan.

existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: Jon Lloyd, head of FIG Sales Europe, at JPMorgan says: “APIs are becoming increasingly important to how we create a better customer experience. APIs enable us to bring services to customer in a faster, more customised way and ClearBank’s approach is indicative of the way in which the market is moving.” Simon Jones, chief customer officer, ClearBank, says customers will benefit from increased liquidity, improved visibility into cash flows, and greater control as the need to transfer funds to third party accounts is removed.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: The move will provide customers with the ability to move funds between accounts with real-time foreign exchange pricing based on interbank rates.

networkOptimisation.content: “Before, there were only two options for firms looking to help their customers hold and move multiple currencies,“ he says. “One, obtain multi-currency capabilities through an electronic money institution but miss out on the functionality of a fully-fledged bank account, or two, work with an established correspondent bank that isn’t API-fluent and lose time-to-market through arduous onboarding processes. With JPMorgan’s deep local currency market experience and ClearBank’s API-enabled products and services, this represents the best of both worlds.”
Client funds will continue to be held at ClearBank, which will act as a conduit to JPmorgan, providing access to multiple currencies, pricing, and execution all via an API.

contentSummary: News reported that Goldman Sachs had added a personal finance management tool to Marcus, its online retail banking service.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: Marcus Insights promises to bring customers' finances together in a single dashboard with smart tools and trackers to give them a clear oversight of their money. Users can link external accounts from thousands of lenders and see their checking, savings, loan, retirement and investment accounts from a single spot.

networkOptimisation.content: The Marcus app can connect with thousands of financial institutions, either through a partnership with fintech firm Plaid, or with direct relationships Goldman has with banks and brokerages.

contentSummary: Lessons learned from Standard Chartered’s open banking journey biggest achievements so far of the Open Banking API Portal created by Standard Chartered

existingPortfolioEnhancement.type: Customer reach, adoption, focusing on existing/traditional bank customer segments
existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: Over 100 APIs listed on external portal, over 10,000 new visitors in 2019, 12+ business leads

Corporate clients use API services to initiate real-time payments and also to get real-time debit/credit notifications. This helps them with improved liquidity and working capital management APIs provide clients with the flexibility to choose appropriate data. The aXess platform will offer developers open access to the bank’s open source code for banking products and its APIs, applications, and libraries. It serves as an adaptive layer in its technology architecture.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: Standard Chartered is active in API Collections for a leading airline in Malaysia from their ticketing agents. Using API and Virtual Account, Standard Chartered was able to assist the airlines in achieving higher efficiency by eliminating manual processes and improve reconciliation from two days to almost in real time.

efficiencyEnhancement.content: Clients want faster and more flexible access to services and data. APIs enable the bank to provide clients with such a service via self-help model

networkOptimisation.content: The bank will be launching an open platform for Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) in India, to help them grow by providing access to a range of financial and business solutions. The technology platform will offer SMEs access to financial and business solutions through a network of partnerships.
The aXess platform will offer developers open access to the bank’s open source code for banking products and its APIs, applications, and libraries.

contentSummary: A case study of IBM's hybrid multicloud - Bank of the Philippine Islands (BPI): BPI is the first bank in the Philippines and Southeast Asia, currently the second largest bank in the Philippines in terms of market capitalization, and one of the most profitable banks in the Philippines. BPI has tapped IBM to accelerate the implementation of its digital banking agenda with a secure, open and scalable hybrid multicloud platform.  They work together to modernise the core IT infrastructure and build an open and integrated API economy, supported by both IBM and third-party public and private cloud providers.

efficiencyEnhancement.content: The new cloud infrastructure helps BPI accelerate its digital transformation, which, by leveraging new technologies, includes faster time-to-market with innovative financial services applications for customers.

contentSummary: News reported that Jetco is pursuing an open banking agenda through an expanded API economy

existingPortfolioEnhancement.type: Customer reach, adoption, focusing on existing/traditional bank customer segments
existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: “Jetco APIX now provides over 540 APIs from 14 banks, covering product and service information including deposit, foreign currency exchange, loans, investment, insurance and other general banking services such as safe deposit box, branch and ATM,” Che outlined.

efficiencyEnhancement.content: “Common platforms like Jetco APIX ensure that all users work in a safe environment and follow the same standards, and undertake due diligence of users,” Che added. “This will result in quicker and more seamless connectivity, and saving a lot of administration time and resources, eventually helping to grow the API market as a whole.

networkOptimisation.content: For Hong Kong-based Che, the challenge centres around persuading enterprises of al sizes to realise the benefits of joining a common platform instead of building proprietary platforms. In response, the fintech specialist launched an API exchange platform in early 2019 to aid open banking development efforts, with Jetco APIX providing connectivity for users in both banking and non-banking sectors. The platform is designed to facilitate the collaboration and co-creation of new products and services in a safe and standardised environment.

contentSummary: News reported that Experian has partnered with Standard Chartered to drive financial access across key markets in Asia, Africa and the Middle East by leveraging credit decisioning technology.

existingPortfolioEnhancement.type: Customer reach, adoption, focusing on existing/traditional bank customer segments
existingPortfolioEnhancement.content: Launched in India in December 2019, Standard Chartered registered positive business outcomes such as increased acceptance rates and reduced overall delinquencies. The success in India meant that Standard Chartered is now able to improve risk management for more clients who previously would have been underbanked.

newPortfolioExpansion.content: In support of Standard Chartered’s digital-first transformation strategy, this machine learning capability provides the bank with the ability to ingest and analyse a high volume of non-bank or, with client consent, alternative data, enabling faster, more effective and accurate credit decisioning, resulting in better risk management for the bank and better outcomes from clients.

networkOptimisation.content: The collaboration involves Experian’s global decisioning solution, PowerCurve Strategy Manager, integrated with machine learning capabilities that will enable the deployment of advanced analytics to help organisations make the most of their data. “Partnerships are central to our digital banking strategy and how we better serve our clients. Experian was a natural choice as a partner given their strong track record in innovation and in driving financial inclusion,” said Aalishaan Zaidi, Global Head, Client Experience, Channels & Digital Banking, Standard Chartered.
Reaffirming a commitment towards financial inclusion, Experian and Standard Chartered are working on plans to deploy the solution across Asia, Africa and the Middle East, in addition to India.
